column1: 23660123|Safety and tolerability of an intratumorally injected DNAzyme, Dz13, in patients
column2: with nodular basal-cell carcinoma: a phase 1 first-in-human trial (DISCOVER).|2013|Melanoma|Lancet|Cho, Eun-Ae
column19: Khachigian, Levon M.|Background: c-Jun, a nuclear transcription factor, is preferentially expressed in
column20: cancer. The study drug Dz13, a deoxyribozyme targeting c-jun mRNA inhibits the
column21: growth of a range of tumors, including basal cell carcinoma (BCC) in murine
column22: models. Aims: The primary objectives of this first-in-class, first-in-human trial
column23: (DISCOVER) Phase I trial (ACTRN12610000162011) were to determine the safety and
column24: tolerability of Dz13 in patients with BCC. A secondary objective was to assess
column25: Dz13 pharmacokinetics, changes in protein expression and cell markers in the
column26: tissue following single intratumoral injection. Methods: Nine patients with
column27: nodular BCC were recruited from Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Sydney, Australia
column28: between 2010 and 2011 and enrolled in three escalating dose groups of three
column29: patients. Each patient received a single intratumoral injected dose of Dz13 (10,
column30: 30 or 100µg) and was monitored over four weeks. The highest dose used in the
column31: trial (100µg), is at the upper limit of solubility of the formulation for a 50µl
column32: injection and was the highest concentration used in the preclinical mouse tumor
column33: studies 1. At each follow up visit, complete physical examination, blood and
column34: urine tests, electrocardiogram and pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic analyses were
column35: performed. BCCs were surgically removed 14 days post-Dz13 injection and compared
column36: with the pre-injection biopsy. Findings: All nine patients completed the study
column37: with no drug-related serious adverse events. No systemic Dz13 exposure was
column38: detected. c-Jun expression was reduced in the BCC of all nine of nine
column39: participants treated with Dz13. The DNAzyme increased Caspase-3, -8, -9, and p53,
column40: reduced Bcl-2 and MMP-9, and stimulated inflammatory and immune cell infiltration
column41: in the tumors. Moreover, five of the nine patients had a reduction in
column42: histological tumor depth. Interpretation: Dz13 is safe, well tolerated, inhibits
column43: its target, and shows no detectable systemic exposure following single

column1: 18083403|Cardiotoxicity Associated with the Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitor Sunitinib.|2007|Melanoma|Lancet|Chu, Tammy F.
column2: Rupnick, Maria A.
column16: Schoen, Frederick J.|Background: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) have advanced cancer treatment.
column17: Sunitinib, a recently-approved, multi-targeted TKI, prolongs survival for
column18: patients with metastatic renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and gastrointestinal stromal
column19: tumor (GIST), but concerns about cardiac safety have arisen with this agent.
column20: Methods: To determine the cardiovascular risk associated with sunitinib, we
column21: reviewed all cardiovascular events in patients with imatinib-resistant,
column22: metastatic GIST at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute enrolled in a Phase I/II
column23: protocol evaluating the efficacy of the drug (n=75). Sunitinib’s effects on left
column24: ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and blood pressure (BP) were also examined.
column25: Studies in isolated cardiomyocytes and mice investigated potential mechanisms of
column26: sunitinib-associated cardiac effects. Findings: Eleven percent (8/75) of subjects
column27: suffered a cardiovascular event with congestive heart failure (CHF) occurring in
column28: 8% (6/75) of the population. Twenty-eight percent (10/36) of patients treated at
column29: the FDA-approved dose had LVEF declines of = 10 EF%, and nineteen percent (7/36)
column30: experienced LVEF declines of = 15 EF%. Sunitinib induced significant increases in
column31: mean systolic and diastolic BP in patients, and 47% (35/75) of individuals
column32: developed hypertension (HTN) (>150/100 mmHg). CHF and LV dysfunction generally
column33: responded to withholding drug and instituting medical management. In mice and
column34: cultured cardiomyocytes, sunitinib caused mitochondrial injury and cardiomyocyte
column35: apoptosis. Interpretation: Sunitinib treatment can lead to HTN, LVEF decline,
column36: and/or CHF. Experimental studies suggest that this is due, at least in part, to
column37: direct cardiomyocyte toxicity which may be exacerbated by HTN. Patients treated
column38: with sunitinib should receive close monitoring and prompt treatment for HTN

column1: 19546414|Cutaneous Malignancies among HIV-Infected Persons.|2009|Melanoma|Archives Of Internal Medicine|Crum-Cianflone, Nancy
column2: Hullsiek, Katherine Huppler
column9: Agan, Brian K.|Background: As life expectancy of HIV-infected persons increases, cancers have
column10: become an important cause of morbidity and mortality. Although cutaneous
column11: neoplasms are the most common malignancies in the general population, little data
column12: exist among HIV-positive persons especially regarding the impact of HIV-specific
column13: factors. Methods: We evaluated the incidence rates and factors associated with
column14: the development of cutaneous malignancies among HIV-infected persons by examining
column15: prospectively collected data from a large HIV Natural History Study composed of
column16: 4,490 persons (1986 to 2006). Poisson regression and Cox proportional hazards
column17: models were performed. Results: Six percent (n=254) of HIV-infected persons
column18: developed a cutaneous malignancy during 33,760 person-years of follow-up (mean
column19: 7.5 years). Since the advent of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART),
column20: incidence rates of cutaneous non-AIDS defining cancers (NADCs), in particular
column21: basal cell carcinoma, have exceeded rates of cutaneous AIDS-defining cancers such
column22: as Kaposi’s sarcoma. Factors associated with the development of cutaneous NADCs
column23: in the multivariate models included increasing age (hazard ratio (HR) 2.1
column25: 1.7–2.6) and race. Compared to white/non-Hispanic race, African Americans (HR
column26: 0.03, 95% CI 0.01–0.14) and other races (HR 0.14, 95% CI 0.03, 0.57) had a lower
column27: risk of cutaneous NADCs. There were no significant associations between cutaneous
column28: NADCs and time-updated CD4 counts, HIV RNA levels, or HAART receipt. Conclusions:
column29: NADCs are now the most common cutaneous malignancies among HIV-infected persons.
column30: Cutaneous NADCs do not appear to be significantly associated with immune function
column31: or HAART, but rather are related to traditional factors, such as aging and skin

column1: 19124815|Association Between Statin Use and Risk for Keratinocyte Carcinoma in the
column2: Veterans Affairs Topical Tretinoin Chemoprevention Trial.|2009|Carcinoma|Annals Of Internal Medicine|Dore, David D.
column6: Weinstock, Martin A.|Background: Recent evidence suggests that statins may prevent cancer. Objective:
column7: To quantify the association between statin use and the occurrence of keratinocyte
column8: carcinoma in high-risk veterans. Design: Cohort study. Setting: 6 Veterans
column9: Affairs medical centers. Participants: 1037 participants of the Veterans Affairs
column10: Topical Tretinoin Chemoprevention Trial, a randomized, multicenter, double-blind,
column11: vehicle-controlled trial of topical tretinoin, 0.1%, for prevention of
column12: keratinocyte carcinoma conducted from November 1998 to November 2004.
column13: Measurements: Time to first occurrence of keratinocyte carcinoma on the face or
column14: ears. Participants using a statin at randomization, according to the Veterans
column15: Affairs Pharmacy Benefits Management database, were considered exposed. Study
column16: dermatologists conducted physical examinations at baseline and every 6 months
column17: during follow-up. The association between statin use at randomization and the
column18: outcome was evaluated by using propensity score matching (n = 608) and Cox
column19: proportional hazards regression (n = 1037). Results: Among the 1037 participants,
column20: 37% used a statin at randomization (n = 397) for a median duration of at least
column21: 900 days over a median follow-up of 3.5 years. In the propensity score-matched
column22: analysis, statin use at randomization was not associated with keratinocyte
column23: carcinoma (rate ratio, 0.92 [95% CI, 0.73 to 1.16]), a finding that was
column24: consistent with the estimates derived from the Cox proportional hazards
column25: regression (rate ratio, 0.84 [CI, 0.70 to 1.02]). Limitations: The extent of
column26: residual confounding is unknown, and the confidence bounds around the measures of
column27: association were wide. These data may not be generalizable to lower-risk
column28: populations. Conclusion: These data show no conclusive or consistent relationship
column29: between long-term statin use and risk for keratinocyte carcinoma. Funding:
column30: Department of Veterans Affairs, Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality,
column31: American Cancer Society, and National Institutes of Health.|19.58

column23: and HT use. The main predictor was screening mammography interval. Results:
column24: Mammography biennially vs annually for women aged 50 to 74 years does not

column26: breast density or HT use. Among women aged 40 to 49 years with extremely dense
column27: breasts, biennial mammography vs annual is associated with increased risk of
column31: 95% CI, 1.37–4.18). Cumulative probability of a false-positive
column32: mammography result was high among women undergoing annual mammography with
column33: extremely dense breasts who were either aged 40 to 49 years (65.5%) or used
column34: estrogen plus progestogen (65.8%) and was lower among women aged 50 to 74 years
column35: who underwent biennial or triennial mammography with scattered fibroglandular
column36: densities (30.7% and 21.9%, respectively) or fatty breasts (17.4% and 12.1%,
column37: respectively). Conclusions and Relevance: Women aged 50 to 74 years, even those
column38: with high breast density or HT use, who undergo biennial screening mammography
column39: have similar risk of advanced-stage disease and lower cumulative risk of
column40: false-positive results than those who undergo annual mammography. When deciding
column41: whether to undergo mammography, women aged 40 to 49 years who have extremely
column42: dense breasts should be informed that annual mammography may minimize their risk
column43: of advanced-stage disease but the cumulative risk of false-positive results is

column1: 18626035|Skin Diseases in Family Medicine: Prevalence and Health Care Use.|2008|Melanoma|Annals Of Family Medicine|Verhoeven, Elisabeth W. M.
column2: Kraaimaat, Floor W.
column4: van de Kerkhof, Peter C. M.
column6: van der Valk, Pieter G. M.
column7: van den Hoogen, Henk J. M.
column10: Evers, Andrea W. M.|PURPOSE Ongoing care for patients with skin diseases can be optimized by
column11: understanding the incidence and population prevalence of various skin diseases
column12: and the patient-related factors related to the use of primary, specialty, and
column13: alternative health care for these conditions. We examined the recent prevalence
column14: of skin diseases in a defined population of family medicine patients,
column15: self-reported disease-related quality of life, extent and duration of skin
column16: disease, and the use of health care by patients with skin diseases.METHODS We
column17: undertook a morbidity registry-based epidemiological study to determine the
column18: prevalence of various skin diseases, using a patient questionnaire to inquire
column19: about health care use, within a network of family practices in the Netherlands
column20: with a practice population of approximately 12,000 citizens.RESULTS Skin diseases
column21: accounted for 12.4% of all diseases seen by the participating family physicians.
column22: Of the 857 questionnaires sent to patients registered with a skin disease, 583
column23: (68.0%) were returned, and 501 were suitable for analysis. In the previous year,
column24: 83.4% of the patients had contacted their family physician for their skin
column25: disease, 17.0% had contacted a medical specialist, and 5.2% had consulted an
column26: alternative health care practitioner. Overall, 65.1% contacted only their family
column27: physician. Patients who reported more severe disease and lower quality of life
column28: made more use of all forms of health care.CONCLUSION This practice
column29: population-based study found that skin diseases account for 12.4% of diseases
column30: seen by family physicians, and that some skin problems may be seen more
column31: frequently. Although patients with more extensive skin diseases also obtain care
column32: from dermatologists, most patients have their skin diseases treated mainly by
column33: their family physician. Overall, patients with more severe disease and a lower
column34: quality of life seek more treatment.|8.97

column1: 21950375|Progress against Cancer (1971–2011): How far have we come?|2012|Melanoma|Journal Of Internal Medicine|Tiwari, Ashish K.
column2: Roy, Hemant K.|“The big C”, a common euphemism for cancer, has loomed large on the collective
column3: psyche of the mankind for centuries, not least because of the relative dearth of
column4: effective treatment against this disease but its ability to relentlessly evade
column5: them and come back to haunt us. However, the struggle against cancer took a
column6: decisive turn in 1971 when a relentless campaigning by health activists
column7: eventually led to signing of the National Cancer Act in the United States, an
column8: unprecedented event in the history of diseases. As we commemorate the 40th
column9: anniversary of the signing of that historic legislation, an assessment of the
column10: progress against cancer would naturally help us understand how we have fared so
column11: far in this struggle, and guide us in our efforts to re-strategize and re-deploy
column12: our limited resources to their best use against this immortal enemy.|7.04

column1: 25116425|Racial, Social, and Clinical Determinants of Hepatocellular Carcinoma
column2: Surveillance.|2015|Melanoma|The American Journal Of Medicine|Singal, Amit G.
column8: Yopp, Adam|Background: Fewer than 1 in 5 patients receive hepatocellular carcinoma
column10: however, most studies were performed in racially and
column11: socioeconomically homogenous populations and few used guideline-based definitions
column12: for surveillance. Aims: To characterize guideline-consistent hepatocellular
column13: carcinoma surveillance rates and identify determinants of hepatocellular
column14: carcinoma surveillance among a racially and socioeconomically diverse cohort of
column15: cirrhotic patients. Methods: We retrospectively characterized hepatocellular
column16: carcinoma surveillance among cirrhotic patients followed between July 2008 and
column17: July 2011 at an urban safety-net hospital. Inconsistent surveillance was defined
column18: as at least one screening ultrasound during the 3-year period, annual
column19: surveillance as screening ultrasounds every 12 months, and biannual surveillance
column20: as screening ultrasounds every 6 months. Univariate and multivariate analyses
column21: were conducted to identify predictors of surveillance. Results: Of 904 cirrhotic
column22: patients, 603 (67%) underwent inconsistent surveillance. Failure to recognize
column23: cirrhosis was a significant barrier to surveillance utilization (p<0.001).
column24: Inconsistent surveillance was associated with insurance status (OR 1.43, 95%CI
column25: 1.03–1.98), multiple primary care visits per year (OR 2.63, 95%CI 1.86–3.71),
column26: multiple hepatology visits per year (OR 3.75, 95%CI 2.64–5.33), African American
column29: (13.4%) of 730 patients underwent annual surveillance, and only 13 (1.7%) of 786
column30: had biannual surveillance. Conclusions: Only 13% of patients with cirrhosis
column31: receive annual surveillance and less than 2% receive biannual surveillance. There
column32: are racial and socioeconomic disparities, with lower rates of hepatocellular
column33: carcinoma surveillance among African Americans and underinsured patients.|6.33

column1: 23747795|First In-human Intraoperative Imaging of HCC using Fluorescence Goggle System and
column2: Transarterial Delivery of Near-infrared Fluorescent Imaging Agent: a Pilot Study.|2013|Melanoma|Translational Research : The Journal Of Laboratory And Clinical Medicine|Liu, Yang
column10: Achilefu, Samuel|Surgical resections remain the primary curative interventions for hepatocellular
column11: carcinoma (HCC). However, lack of real-time intraoperative image guidance
column12: confines surgeons to subjective visual assessment of the surgical bed, leading to
column13: poor visualization of small positive nodules and the extension of diffuse HCC. To
column14: address this problem, we developed a wearable fluorescence imaging and display
column15: system (fluorescence goggle) for intraoperative imaging of HCCs in human
column16: patients. In this pilot study, both intravenous (i.v.) and transarterial hepatic
column17: (TAH) delivery of indocyanine green (ICG) were explored to facilitate
column18: fluorescence goggle-mediated HCC imaging. The results show that all primary
column19: tumors in patients (n=4) who received TAH delivery of ICG were successfully
column20: identified by the fluorescence goggle. In addition, 6 satellite tumors were also
column21: detected by the goggle, 5 of which were neither identifiable in pre-operative MRI
column22: and CT images nor by visual inspection and palpation. In the group (n=5) that
column23: received ICG by i.v., only 2 out of 6 tumors visible in the pre-operative MRI or
column24: CT images were identified with the fluorescence goggle, demonstrating the
column25: limitation of this delivery route for a non-tumor selective imaging agent.
column26: Comparative analysis shows that the HCC-to-liver florescence contrast detected by
column27: the goggle was significantly higher in patients that received TAH than i.v.
column28: delivery of ICG (P=0.013). This pilot study demonstrates the feasibility of using
column29: the fluorescence goggle to identify multifocal lesions and small tumor deposits
column30: using TAH ICG delivery in HCC patients.|6.03

column9: Abnet, Christian C.|Background: Few studies have investigated the relationship of physical activity

column13: women, followed from 1995–1996 to December 31, 2003. All analyses were performed
column14: in 2007– 2008. Results: During 8 years of follow-up study, 523 cases of
column15: esophageal carcinoma (149 squamous cell and 374 adenocarcinoma) and 642 cases of
column16: gastric carcinoma (313 cardia and 329 noncardia) were documented. Physical
column17: activity was associated with reduced risk of esophageal and gastric
column18: adenocarcinomas but was unrelated to esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. The
column19: inverse association with physical activity was strongest for gastric noncardia
column20: adenocarcinoma (multivariate relative risk [RR] for highest versus lowest
column21: physical activity level=0.62, 95% CI=0.44, 0.87). Relationships were weaker but
column26: relationship with physical activity was observed for esophageal squamous cell
column28: 95% CI=0.64, 1.74). Exclusion of cases diagnosed during the
column29: first 2 follow-up years did not change those estimates, indicating that the
column30: findings are not due to decreased activity levels among participants with
column31: undiagnosed cancer at entry. Conclusions: Physical activity may play a role in
column32: the prevention of upper gastrointestinal tract adenocarcinomas. No association
column33: was seen between physical activity and esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.|5.36

column1: 25423295|A Case of the Intrapulmonary Spread of Recurrent Respiratory Papillomatosis With
column2: Malignant Transformation.|2015|Carcinoma|The American Journal Of The Medical Sciences|Xiao, Yang
column5: Ma, Lijing|Objectives:: To describe an individual with recurrent respiratory papillomatosis
column6: that extended into the lung parenchyma and underwent malignant transformation and
column7: to discuss the characteristic imaging findings associated with this condition.
column8: Methods:: The clinical presentation of an individual with this unusual malignant
column9: transformation was reviewed. A literature search was performed to characterize
column10: the epidemiology, imaging findings and management of this condition. Results::
column11: The patient underwent 30 courses of surgery over 21 years and presented
column12: disseminated pulmonary papilloma after childbirth. The interval between
column13: dissemination into the lung and malignant transformation was 2.5 years. The
column14: tracheal papilloma was positive for type 6 of human papilloma virus (HPV-6). She
column15: died because she refused further treatment. Conclusions:: The clinician should
column16: have a high index of suspicion for lung papillomatosis in patients with a
column17: tracheotomy. Appropriate diagnostic imaging studies will be helpful in reaching
column18: this diagnosis and determining whether a malignancy exists. Treatment options
column19: have limited success when lung papillomatosis becomes malignant.|4.86

column1: 19705306|MicroRNAs: critical mediators of differentiation, development and disease.|2009|Carcinoma|Swiss Medical Weekly|Friedman, Jeffrey M.
column2: Jones, Peter A.|MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are small non-coding RNAs that are expressed in higher
column3: eukaryoates and have even been found in viral genomes. They usually act as
column4: endogenous repressors of target genes by either inhibiting translation, causing
column5: mRNA degradation, or by a combination of both mechanisms. More than 850 mature
column6: miRNA sequences have been identified in humans, and although this accounts for
column7: less than 2% of human genes, it is predicted that 30% of mRNAs are targeted by
column8: miRNAs. miRNAs play critical roles in most cellular processes including
column9: development, differentiation, and the homeostasis of both a cell and an organism.
column10: Moreover, many disease states, including cancer, occur or are sustained by miRNA
column11: dysregulation. Here we will review the latest reports of miRNA involvement and
column12: aberrant expression in human disease with an emphasis on cancer.|4.16

column1: 19122835|Educating osteopaths to be researchers – what role should research methods and
column2: statistics have in an undergraduate curriculum?|2008|Carcinoma|International Journal Of Osteopathic Medicine : Ijom|Licciardone, John C.|Evidence-based medicine (EBM) involves using research data to enhance the
column3: diagnosis and treatment of clinical disorders. Somatic dysfunction and
column4: osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) are two unique aspects of osteopathy
column5: that will benefit from a greater emphasis on scientific evidence. Most evidence
column6: in osteopathy is based on expert opinions, case reports, case series, and

column9: demonstrates the efficacy of OMT for low back pain, other clinical trials are

column11: curricula should ensure that students acquire the tools necessary to become
column12: knowledgeable consumers of the research and statistics presented in biomedical
column13: journals. Such curricula need to be supplemented with graduate training programs
column14: and research funding mechanisms to ensure that young osteopathic researchers are
column15: able to produce the research needed to practice and advance evidence-based

column1: 26109557|AGO Austria recommendations for genetic testing of patients with ovarian cancer.|2015|Carcinoma|Wiener Klinische Wochenschrift|Marth, Christian
column2: Hubalek, Michael
column10: Zeimet, Alain G.|In Austria, 700 women are diagnosed every year with ovarian carcinoma.
column11: Approximately 15?% of the patients with epithelial ovarian cancer have a germline
column12: mutation in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes. The increased incidence of breast and/or
column13: ovarian cancer in genetically related family members has given rise to the term
column14: “hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome” (HBOC). Some 25–55?% of these
column15: in-family diseases are attributed to germline mutations of BRCA1 or BRCA2, and
column16: approximately 5–10?% to other known tumor predisposition syndromes. The remaining
column17: persons may carry mutations in as yet unidentified genes. HBOC caused by BRCA1
column18: and BRCA2 mutations is an autosomal dominant disorder with high penetrance. BRCA1
column19: and BRCA2 encode for so-called tumor suppressor proteins. Inherited functional
column20: mutations of these genes cause loss of function of the respective allele. Loss of
column21: function of the second allele causes complete loss of the corresponding protein
column22: and facilitates the development of a malignancy.The Association of Gynecologic
column23: Oncology recommends that testing for a germline mutation in BRCA1 or BRCA2 should
column24: be offered to all patients with epithelial ovarian cancer. When mutations in
column25: BRCA1, BRCA2, or other cancer-susceptibility genes have been identified, patients
column26: with ovarian carcinoma can be treated with new, innovative therapies. This
column27: recommendation is intended as a standard guideline for genetic testing of

column1: 23273237|The gastro-esophageal malignancies in Northern Iran research project: impact on
column2: the health research and health care systems in Iran.|2013|Melanoma|Archives Of Iranian Medicine|Sepanlou, Sadaf G.
column18: Malekzadeh, Reza|Since 2000, considerable progress has been made in health research in Iran. An
column19: example of this progress has been the Gastro- Esophageal Malignancies in Northern
column20: Iran (GEMINI). The original aim of this project was to identify etiologic factors
column21: and prevention measures for upper gastrointestinal cancers in Northern provinces
column22: of Iran, but its achievements have gone much beyond the initial goal. This
column23: project is one of the largest studies in the Middle East and North African
column24: region, has helped build and strengthen research capacity at both individual and
column25: institutional levels in Iran, and has provided international credibility to
column26: research institutes and the wider research system in Iran. The success of GEMINI
column27: reveals the feasibility of large-scale studies in developing countries and serves
column28: as a successful model not only for health research institutes within Iran, but
column29: also for research systems in other developing countries. The outcomes of the
column30: project are numerous, including establishment of research networks, development
column31: of efficient methods for planning and implementation of research projects, and
column32: introduction of methodologies for project management, data management and usage
column33: of health technology. Finally and perhaps most importantly, GEMINI is among the
column34: few projects that has had a significant impact on the attitudes and concerns of
column35: decision makers in the health sector in Iran. It signifies the importance of
column36: investment in human resources and has proved that health policies should be
column37: health-based rather than patient-based. Here we review the impact of GEMINI on
column38: the health research system and the broader health care system of Iran and put
column39: these into a more global perspective.|1.92

column1: 25336875|Treating medullary thyroid carcinoma in a tertiary center. Current trends and
column2: review of the literature.|2014|Carcinoma|Hippokratia|Prokopakis, E
column7: Velegrakis, G|Objectives:: We present the clinical outcome and long-term survival in patients
column8: with medullary thyroid carcinoma treated in a tertiary center. A thorough review
column9: of published series and current therapeutic approaches is also addressed. Study
column10: Design:: A retrospective review Setting:: An Academic Tertiary center
column11: Subjects/Methods:: An analysis of oncologic outcomes from 25 patients treated in
column12: our department for medullary thyroid carcinoma is performed, together with a
column13: comparison of relevant studies over the literature. Results:: The incidence of
column14: patients alive free of disease and the 5-year survival rate has been noticed to
column15: be slightly higher than the rate reported in most series. Conclusions:: Total
column16: thyroidectomy and neck dissection remains the gold standard in the treatment of
column17: medullary thyroid carcinoma. Early diagnosis and aggressive surgical treatment
column18: lead to lower rates of recurrence and invasiveness. Tyrosine-kinase inhibitor,
column19: especially vantetanib, appears to be a promising target for treatment.|1.44
